abstracts.cdata!:
The Requesters claim that the Bank did
            not take the rights and interests of the Garifuna people
            into consideration in the design, appraisal and
            implementation of the Honduras Land Administration Project
            and violated its own policies and procedures; and that the
            Bank's acts and omissions will endanger the survival of
            the Garifuna people. Specifically among the complaints, the
            Requestors note that the project is supposed to provide for
            ancestral lands to be regularized in favor of indigenous and
            Afro-Honduran populations by recognizing communal or
            individual land rights, based on the preference of each
            community, and by registering such rights in the land
            registry. However, the Requesters fear that the land titling
            and procedures provided will ultimately cause the demise of
            collective property in favor of individual property, which
            is contrary to the land tenure system they prefer, and could
            give their land, which they consider as their functional
            habitat, to people outside the Garifuna communities.
            Furthermore the Requestors assert that Bank staff did not
            consult with affected people prior to preparing the
            Indigenous Peoples Development Plan (IPDP); that they made a
            draft property law to which they are firmly opposed the
            centerpiece of the land titling program, and this law
            provides for a land titling and conflicts resolution
            procedure that is different from the one outlined in the
            project documents; the conflict resolution method in the
            IPDP-arbitration -- not only is unconstitutional but
            different from the one provided for in the property law; the
            applicable procedures for indigenous peoples to file
            territorial claims is confusing; and the environmental
            analysis does not provide for the Garifuna people to manage
            or co-manage their land to restore their control over the
            functional habitat they preserved for centuries. In response
            to these complaints, Bank Management focuses on four points:
            1) When activities are implemented, appropriate safeguards
            are built into the project to protect indigenous
            people's lands. 2) Community participation in the
            project is voluntary and broad participatory mechanisms are
            operational. 3) The project complies with national
            legislation as well as with Bank policies. 4) Management has
            responded to the Requestor's concerns and "remains
            committed to ongoing meaningful consultations that include
            Garifuna stakeholders.
